PUBLIC. This information is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

I.  THE ONGOING PROGRAM 
  
1.  The Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program (TSCFP) works with partner financial 
institutions (PFIs) to close financing gaps of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The 
Supply Chain Finance Program (SCFP) arm of TSCFP operates in 10 of ADB’s developing 
member countries (DMCs) and has seen rapid growth recently. In 2020, SCFP supported 1,447 
transactions, an increase of 151% from the previous year, with the overall transaction value 
increasing 108% to $246 million.   
 
2.  Being complementary programs, SCFP and ADB’s Trade Finance Program (TFP) were 
operationally merged in 2020 into the Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program (TSCFP). 
Whereas TFP takes bank risk to support cross border trade, SCFP shares corporate risk with 
partner financial institutions to support both domestic and cross-border supply chains. While TFP 
has scaled into one of ADB’s largest businesses–in 2020, TFP supported over 7,000 transactions 
valued at $5.8 billion–the SCFP is small but growing rapidly. Merging these two businesses is 
helping SCFP scale up by leveraging off TFP’s existing relationships and experience, while 
achieving operational efficiency and delivering even better client service.  
 
3.  TSCFP  is  central  to  ADB’s  response  to  the  COVID-19  pandemic.1 Of  the  13,000 
transactions supported under TFP over 2020 and 2021, several supported COVID vaccine 
imports, test kits, and medical equipment.2  The transactions supported companies that provided 
essential  services  and  financial  intermediaries  that  granted  direct  financing  to  individual 
companies, including SMEs, or facilitated local, regional, and global trade and related supply 
chains  materially  affected  by  the  pandemic’s  economic  fallout.  Of  the  1,447  transactions 
supported under SCFP, 1,288 were COVID-related transactions worth $211 million. Of this, 1,058 
transactions  valued  at  $185  million  provided  support  to  the  pharmaceutical  sector,  with  a 
particular focus on SMEs. 
 
4.  TSCFP helps deliver Sustainable Development Goals through its various knowledge 
products, services and solutions, including ones targeted at promoting sustainability in trade, 
ensuring integrity and transparency in supply chains, as well as helping accelerate progress in 
gender equality.3 In addition, TSCFP produced knowledge products such as the COVID-19 supply 
chain mapping tool.4  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The Trade Finance Gaps, Growth and Job Survey published in October 2021 showed a 
global trade finance gap of $1.7 trillion, with more than 40% of rejected trade finance transactions 
 
 
1  ADB. 2020. ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic. Manila.

help developing economies in Asia and the Pacific purchase vaccines and related equipment needed to fight COVID-
19. The facility provides guarantees through the program’s network of partner banks to support the purchase of 
vaccines, as well as glass vials, syringes, and equipment for cold chain storage facilities. Through risk sharing with 
partner banks, the $500 million facility can be leveraged to $1 billion.

chains. The tool helps banks, investors and government ensure companies have no bottlenecks and financial support 
is there to ramp up supply.

2 
coming from SMEs.5 The gap has grown over the course of the pandemic and is likely getting 
larger as inflation raises the value of transactions, thereby lowering the ability of existing country 
and counterparty financing limits exist to meet demand. The gap is exacerbated by a lack of 
capacity on the part of both SMEs and the local banks that is needed to provide supply chain 
finance. Regulatory gaps are also constraining SME growth and support.  
 
6.  Recognizing TSCFP’s growing expertise in implementing supply chain finance in banks 
across ADB’s developing member countries, the United States Department of State has invited 
the TSCFP to submit a proposal to aid SMEs in the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral 
Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC) Region to overcome factors constraining their 
access to trade. The State Department aims to catalyze economic growth in the BIMSTEC Region 
and views TSCFP’s experience in supply chain finance capacity development as a good vehicle 
through which to implement its objectives. 
 
7.  Closing SME finance gaps, which have widened during the global pandemic, delivers 
significant development impact by furthering growth and job creation and therefore reducing 
poverty. The TSCFP is well placed to close these gaps by: (i) expanding SCFP, which delivers 
finance to SMEs, with the aim of onboarding DMC banks as partner financial institutions (PFIs) 
after 3-4 quarters of intensive capacity building in supply chain finance; (ii) working with PFIs to 
develop their capacity to support more SMEs, including through supply chain finance, and in 
training on issues related to SME financing, such as anti-money-laundering and sustainability; (iii) 
providing capacity building to SMEs themselves on understanding the benefits of supply chain 
finance and how it works, as well as how to attract financing; and (iv) working as One ADB to 
close legislative gaps, including for the provision of supply chain finance, which impede greater 
support for SMEs. 
 
8.  The proposed $2,222,200 technical assistance (TA)6 would support SME capacity building 
in Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. The anticipated outcome of the TA will be expanded 
uptake of supply chain finance in ADB DMCs in said BIMSTEC countries. Planned activities under 
the proposed TA are categorized as follows: 
 
(i)  intense  capacity  building  including  the  provision  of  supply  chain  finance 
information technology software, as necessary, for five DMC banks to enable them 
to provide supply chain finance to SMEs and apply gender lens financing; 
(ii)  training for a wider array of DMC banks and corporate clients who have SME 
suppliers. The TA will provide supply chain finance, gender, anti-money-laundering, 
and sustainability-related online training, webinars, and face-to-face training post-
pandemic; and  
(iii)  regulatory  work  to  review  and  identify  gaps  in  local  supply  chain  finance 
regulations.  
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  and  promotes  Operational  Priority  1: 
Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities Pillar 2 Quality Jobs Generated.7 
Through TSCFP’s gender equity and safeguards initiatives, the TA supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 
Operational Priorities 2 and 3. The proposed capacity building and knowledge-sharing activities 
under the TA demonstrate ADB’s role as a knowledge institution and knowledge provider. The TA
